name: Pauli-X rotation gate
description: Sometimes known as the "bit-flip" or "NOT" gate, as it transforms \(\ket{0}\) to \(\ket{1}\) and vice versa. On the Bloch sphere, this is a rotation of \(\pi\) in the X axis.

name: Pauli-Y rotation gate
description: Maps \(\ket{0}\) to \(i\ket{1}\) and \(\ket{1}\) to \(-i\ket{0}\). On the Bloch sphere, this is a rotation of \(\pi\) in the Y axis.

name: Pauli-Z rotation gate
description: The same as an X gate followed by a Y, this maps \(\ket{0}\) to itself and \(\ket{1}\) to \(-\ket{1}\). On the Bloch sphere, this is a rotation of \(\pi\) in the Z axis.

name: S phase-shift gate
description: Equivalent to half of the Z gate: a rotation of \(\pi/2\) in the Z axis.

name: T phase-shift gate
description: Equivalent to a quarter of the Z gate: a rotation of \(\pi/4\) in the Z axis.

name: \(T^\dagger\) phase-shift gate
description: The opposite of the T gate: a rotation of \(-\pi/4\) in the Z axis.

name: Controlled X gate
description: Also known as the controlled NOT gate. Will leave the source qubit alone if the control qubit is \(\ket{0}\), and perform the X gate on the source qubit (\(\ket{0}\) ↔ \(\ket{1}\)) if the control qubit is \(\ket{1}\). If the control qubit is another state, this causes entanglement.

name: Controlled Y gate
description: Will leave the source qubit alone if the control qubit is \(\ket{0}\), and perform the Y gate on the source qubit if the control qubit is \(\ket{1}\). If the control qubit is another state, this causes entanglement.

name: Controlled Z gate
description: Will leave the source qubit alone if the control qubit is \(\ket{0}\), and perform the Z gate on the source qubit if the control qubit is \(\ket{1}\). If the control qubit is another state, this causes entanglement.

name: Qubit-swap gate
description: Swaps two qubit values between registers. This does not entangle.

name: Toffoli gate (aka ccX or ccNOT)
description: Much like the cX gate, will apply the X (aka the NOT) gate if both control qubits are \(\ket{1}\), with entanglement for qubits neither \(\ket{0}\) nor \(\ket{1}\)
